entry.title: Combined summary - Proposal for an Informational BIP
entry.summary: An email conversation on the bitcoin-dev mailing list discusses a proposal for a new method of introducing two-factor authentication called the 'quantum' passphrase. The proposed passphrase uses only BIP39 'mnemonic' seed words and offers an exponential increase in the level of protection, as that offered by the original BIP39 mnemonic seed words. This method of passphrase generation consists of generating the BIP39 mnemonic seed words using a BIP39-compatible hardware wallet and converting these seed words into the 'quantum' passphrase following four simple rules which do not destroy the integrity of the initial data.The proposed 'quantum' passphrase offers several advantages over existing methods of multi-factor protection, including discouraging user-created words or sentences and providing plausible deniability in case of coercion. A two-wallet configuration provides the user with an opportunity to safely split the two factors of protection. The proposed method encourages physical backup of the passphrase and uses only BIP39-only words to provide a higher degree of standardization, avoiding potential mistakes made by creating unnecessarily complicated combinations of letters, numbers, and symbols. The proposed passphrase aims to provide a very safe and secure 'low-tech' option that requires minimal (non-destructive) adjustments to the seed words.The proposal sent by Chris Johnston to the bitcoin-dev mailing list introduces an optional method for producing a BIP39 passphrase. This method uses only BIP39 'mnemonic' seed words and is referred to as a 'quantum' passphrase. It offers an exponential increase in the level of protection compared to the original BIP39 mnemonic seed words, resulting in approximately 2048^23 possible combinations. The proposal suggests using a separate wallet with 24 seed words to introduce two-factor authentication and protect a Bitcoin wallet without the use of any additional hardware or software.The 'quantum' passphrase can add an extra layer of security to a Bitcoin wallet, making it impossible to brute-force the wallet without the passphrase. The passphrase consists of up to 96 characters and can be easily created from a genuine 24 seed word mnemonic, thereby providing plausible deniability in case of coercion. Using BIP39-only words provides a higher degree of standardization and avoids potential mistakes made by creating unnecessarily complicated combinations of letters, numbers, and symbols. Following just four non-destructive BIP39-compatible rules, the 24 seed words can also function as a quantum passphrase: only BIP39 words, only the first four letters of each word, only uppercase letters, and no spaces between words.The proposed 'quantum' passphrase discourages user-created words or sentences and encourages physical backup of the passphrase. The intention is to promote productive technical discussion on the topic, with links provided to the bitcoin-dev mailing list and a subscription page for those interested in joining the discussion.Chris Johnston welcomes productive technical discussion on his proposal and responds to criticisms by arguing that the proposal was not "rolling your own security" and was instead a non-destructive adaptation of the BIP39 standard. Tobias questions whether such a suggestion is necessary but acknowledges its potential usefulness. The email conversation between Tobias and Chris also discusses the advantages of the 'quantum' passphrase over existing methods of multi-factor protection, issues such as plausible deniability, compatibility with BIP39, and the 'chicken-egg' problem. The large amount of data required to produce a 'quantum' passphrase encourages the physical backup of the passphrase. Overall, the proposal aims to provide an extremely safe and secure 'low-tech' option that requires minimal adjustments to the seed words, providing plausible deniability in case of coercion.
